The crux of the matter here is why do you feel you need to prove your innocence from being a walking biohazard?

Why are you being discriminated against based on your immunity status? 9/n

The conclusion is that no one test can give you the full picture of the complexity of the immune response. 

Meanwhile, Big Pharma will take advantage of your fears and make more tests for you to purchase and obsess about. 8/n

4) T Cells last longer. So a test measuring T cells would show that you've had COVID. There are however multiple T cells each for different parts of the virus. This test is rarely used because it is more expensive and more time-consuming. 7/n

3) A (+) Antibody test is a clear indication that you've had COVID but a (-) antibody test does not rule out that you've had COVID. Antibodies wane off over a 3 months period. They are no longer detected after that although you would be still immune to COVID. 6/n

There isn't a single test that can tell you if you have already had COVID 19 with 100% certainty.
1) A (+) PCR test with characteristic symptoms is more likely to indicate that you've had COVID
2) A (+) PCR test without symptoms cannot clearly determine that you've had COVID 5/n

Fever is an inflammatory response that fights off any invader by activating the immune system or hindering the activity of the invader. 
The body can also launch a specific immune response with cells that target specific invaders. These can be measured to show immunity. 4/n

Here's a simplistic display of immunity levels.
There are immune barriers that protect the body from invaders. If the invader manages to go past them, the body launches a non-specific response. For-example phagocytes are cells that can attack any invader. 3/n https://t.co/4ixExkKExC

A new testing craze is being unleashed.
People are asking me which test can I use to prove that I got COVID. There isn't an easy answer. 
The immune system is complex and can take care of a virus through multiple mechanisms sometimes without leaving a trail of evidence. 2/n
